title: 111_hr4032
content: Credit for certain home purchases. The text chunk discusses the elimination of the first-time homebuyer requirement for the home purchase credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment removes the specific qualification and broadens it to anyone purchasing a principal residence. Conforming amendments are made to related sections in the Code. The Code is amended to change "homebuyer credit" to "home purchase credit" and make clerical amendments to related sections in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The home purchase credit amendments apply to residences purchased after the enactment date. An extension pushes the deadline to December 1, 2010, with a waiver of recapture until that date. An election allows purchases in 2010 to be treated as if made in 2009. The amendments to the home purchase credit allow purchases after November 30, 2009, with an extension to December 1, 2010. There is a modification to the gross income limitation, increasing the limits to $300,000 and $150,000. The amendments to the home purchase credit increase the gross income limitation to $300,000 and $150,000. The changes apply to residences purchased after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a waiver of recapture for individuals on qualified official extended duty, specifically for members of the armed forces. The amendments to the home purchase credit increase the gross income limitation to $300,000 and $150,000 for residences purchased after the Act's enactment. There is a waiver of recapture for individuals on qualified official extended duty, such as members of the armed forces. The term 'qualified official extended duty service' refers to service in the uniformed services, Foreign Service of the United States, or intelligence community. The amendment made by this subsection is effective immediately. The amendment made by this subsection applies to dispositions and cessations after December 31, 2008.
